story.text: AMSTERDAM Global sales of semiconductors reached $22.7 billion in November, an increase of 11.3 percent from the $20.4 billion in November 2005, according to a survey published on Tuesday. Sales increased by 3.1 percent from the $22.0 billion reported in October, the Semiconductor Industry Association (SIA) said in a statement. The November sales figure was the fifth consecutive month of record sales. For the first 11 months of 2006, worldwide semiconductor sales totaled $225.1 billion, an increase of 9.4 percent from the same period in 2005. "Global sales of semiconductors for the first 11 months of 2006 are in line with the SIA forecast of 9.4 percent growth for the year. 2007 is shaping up to be another good year for the industry with a forecast of 10 percent growth over 2006," SIA president George Scalise said in a statement. Consumer demand for products such as digital cameras and flat televisions, which contain large amounts of processing and memory chips, drove semiconductor sales in November, even though the growth pace slowed from the beginning of the year. Semiconductor product lines that showed good month-on-month growth included digital signal processors, which rose 12.3 percent, and DRAM and Flash memory chips which rose by 6.8 percent and 6.3 percent respectively. Large chip makers like Texas Instruments TXN.N and NXP have warned in recent weeks that demand for some chips, in particular for those in mobile phones, had slowed in the fourth quarter because of the popularity of cheaper phone models which contain fewer chips.
story.title: global chip sales rise 11 . 3 percent in nov 2006 : sia
